title:
Kinematical breaking of symmetry : A physical interpretation of
  Brout-Englert-Higgs mechanism

sections.text:
#### Abstract

A new interpretation of the Brout-Englert-Higgs (BEH) mechanism is proposed. The quantum vacuum before symmetry is broken is not a quiet state, but a relativistic many-body state in which virtual massless fermions and antifermions, taking both timelike and spacelike paths, rapidly appear and disappear. In order to give a physical meaning to their many-body state, they should be described so that they move along a common direction of time from the past to the future, even if they are observed from any inertial frame. The state satisfying this kinematical condition is examined, and as its lowest-energy-state, the broken-symmetry vacuum is derived. Since it is a kinematical breaking of symmetry, the interaction is freed from the role of causing symmetry breaking. Whatever effective interaction is there, it induces the motion of others, then turns out to be an inertial mass of the fermion or antifermion. In this physical vacuum, virtual massless fermions and antifermions always appear as pairs, and they behave as quasi bosons. Due to Bose statistics, their transverse excitations are suppressed by an energy gap, which explains the origin of the vacuum condensate in the BEH mechanism. The dynamic part of the above effective interaction induces a Higgs-like excitation. This interpretation sheds a new light on the BEH mechanism.

# I. INTRODUCTION 

The Higgs particle found in 2012 has been extensively examined in experiments [1] [2]. For the electroweak interaction, the Glashaw-Weinberg-Salam (GWS) model [3][4][5], using the Brout-Englert-Higgs (BEH) mechanism [6] [7], does not contradict almost all experimental results to date. The BEH mechanism is a simple model in which both of symmetry breaking and its consequence are derived by adding, to the original Lagrangian density, the following gauge coupling, Higgs potential and Yukawa interaction

$$
L_{h}(x)=\left|\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right) h\right|^{2}-\mu^{2}|h|^{2}-\lambda|h|^{4}-\frac{m_{f}}{v_{h}} h \bar{\varphi} \varphi
$$

Switching the sign of $\mu^{2}$ leads to the broken-symmetry vacuum with the vacuum condensate $v_{h}$. This $v_{h}$ gives a mass $m_{B}=g v_{h}$ to the vector-Abelian-gauge field $B_{\mu}$, and $h$ becomes $v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}$ composed of the Higgs field $h_{1}$ and the Goldstone mode $h_{2}$. As for the fermion's mass $m_{f}$, it is substantially a free parameter. The Higgs potential explains many phenomena using a small number of parameters. This is because it plays a double role: the role of causing symmetry breaking in vacuum and that of predicting the Higgs particle's mass. Furthermore, it stabilizes the broken-symmetry vacuum, and it represents the interaction between the Higgs particle. In this sense, the Higgs potential is a simple and economical model, and it also has the flexibility to adopt to complex situations of the eletroweak interaction. So far, the Higgs coupling to the fermions, especially those of the third generation, have been well parameterized using the Yukawa interaction of fermions to the $h_{1}$.

For its simplicity, however, we face some difficult problems. The switch of the sign of $\mu^{2}$ is an ad hoc assumption without explanation. The origin of the vacuum condensate $v_{h}$ is not clear. When the Higgs potential is used in the perturbation calculation, we must care a lot about the intricate cancellation of the quadratic divergence, and the fine-tuning problem arises. In order to understand the physics behind this phenomenological potential, we need to look at the problem from a somewhat different angle.

It is not correct that the quantum vacuum is quiet with hardly any excitation. The completely quiet Fock vacuum is a too idealized assumption. Let us examine, according to the basic premise of relativistic quantum field theory, the physical vacuum of primitive world in which fermions and gauge bosons are still massless. If we consider massless particles to be real entities, they become a subject of consideration based on the theory of relativity.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

FIG. 1. In the scattering of two massless fermions, the relativistic two-body states (represented by thick lines with arrows) appear as the intermediate state of the fourth-order perturbation process. Four types of combination exists on the direction of time in the two fermions, if the antifermion is not introduced.
(1) In the primitive world before the mass generation of fermions, the number of massless fermion is not fixed due to pair production [8].
(2) In the primitive world before the mass generation of gauge boson, the gauge interaction is still a long-range one.

We can peep at such a state through relativistic intermediate states in the scattering of massless fermions. As a simplest example of the relativistic intermediate state, consider the direct scattering of two massless Dirac fermions, and regard its intermediate state as a relativistic virtual two-body state. Figure. 1 shows its fourth-order process, in which particles take not only timelike but also spacelike path [9]. If we hypothesize the primitive world so that the long-range force mediates scattering to infinitely-high-order of perturbation, these intermediate states continue to exist eternally [10]. In this world, massless fermions take not only timelike but also spacelike paths. By referring to these intermediate states, let's formulate the physical vacuum as a lowest-energy state of the primitive world.

The antiparticles are essential for the formulation of causality and unitarity in the relativistic world. Do they have important implications also for the symmetry breaking such as the mass generation of massless fermions ? Historically, Stueckelberg first stressed the interpretation of backward-in-tine motion [11], and later Feynman independently used it for an intuitive explanation of the raison d'etre of antiparticle [12]. If the concept of backward-in-tine motion is literally applied to the spacelike path in the virtual many-body state, there

will be an object coming from the future to the present, and its relation to other objects coming from the past cannot be described logically. Figure 1 shows the 4th-order process of the 2-body scattering, and 4 combinations of temporal order appears. (In the $2 n$-th order process of the $N$-body scattering, $(2 N)^{n-1}$ combinations of different temporal order appear in the intermediate states.) In order to describe relativistic virtual many-body states logically, we should assume that all bodies there, whether there are causal relations between them or not, proceed along a common direction of time from the past to the future. (If local inversion of temporal order is allowed, it makes a consistent interpretation impossible.) In quantum field theory with infinite degrees of freedom, there are inequivalent representations of the same canonical commutation relation so that they are realized in different Hilbert spaces entailing spontaneous symmetry breaking. The form of representation should be decided by the human side so as to maintain logical consistency. The form determined by the above requirement is an example of it. The representation for the primitive world should be chosen as follows: Time in the relativistic virtual many-body state, even if viewed from any inertial frame, should progress while maintaining the direction of time in each particle.

This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we explain the above requirement, using a simple Lagrangian density,

$$
L_{0}(x)=-\frac{1}{4} F^{\mu \nu} F_{\mu \nu}+\bar{\varphi}\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi
$$

where $\varphi$ is a massless Dirac fermi field [13],

$$
\varphi(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{V}} \sum_{p, s}\left[a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) u^{s}(p) e^{-i p x}+b^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) v^{s}(p) e^{i p x}\right]
$$

In Section 3, we confirm that the lowest-energy state satisfying the above requirement is a broken-symmetry vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$. In contrast to dynamical symmetry breaking, this symmetry breaking comes from the kinematical consideration which embodies the above requirement. As a result, whatever effective interaction acts on fermions, regardless of being repulsive or attractive, it gives a mass to the fermion. Such a vacuum cannot be described using only fundamental constants. Rather, we need parameters as if physical vacuum is a kind of matter having necessary properties of vacuum. The $v_{h}, \mu$ and $\lambda$ in Eq.(1) are such constants. The question is how to introduce these constants in a physically natural way. In Section 4, we explain that virtual massless pairs of fermion and antifermion in the vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ obey Bose statistics, and discuss that this vacuum is rigid on the transverse perturbations. In

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

FIG. 2. (a) The motion of a massless Dirac fermion perturbed by $U_{1}$ and $U_{2}$ at $A$ and $B\left(t_{2}>t_{1}\right)$. (b) When viewed from a fast-moving inertial frame $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$, the order of two events separated by spacelike interval is reversed $\left(t_{2}^{\prime}<t_{1}^{\prime}\right)$.

Section.5, with this rigidity, we propose an origin of the vacuum condensate $v_{h}$. In this interpretation, Higgs particle is a byproduct of symmetry breaking, and we calculate its mass $m_{H}$ as an excitation energy in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ in Section 6 . For these purpose, we define three constants of the vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$, (1) a coherence length $l_{c}$ within which Bose statistics holds on these pairs, (2) a mean distance $d_{m}$ between these pairs, and (3) an upper energy-momentum end $\Lambda$ of the excitation in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$. Parameters in the Higgs potential will be explained in terms of these constants. In Section 7, we discuss implications of this interpretation on the BEH mechanism.

# II. TIME DIRECTION IN RELATIVISTIC VIRTUAL MASSLESS FERMIONS 

Consider the second-order perturbation process of a moving massless Dirac fermion under disturbances in Figure.2(a). There are two disturbances, $U_{1}$ in $A$ at a time $t_{1}$, and $U_{2}$ in $B$ at a later time $t_{2}$, in which the second disturbance $U_{2}$ restore the fermion to its original state with a momentum $\boldsymbol{p}$. Such an amplitude is calculated by summing all possible, timelike or spacelike, intermediate states between $A$ and $B$ over their momenta $\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}$. Suppose that in the inertial system of a coordinate $(\boldsymbol{x}, t)$, a fermion with a negative electric charge and momentum $\boldsymbol{p}$ leave $A$ at $x_{1}$ and $t_{1}$, and reach $B$ at $x_{2}$ and $t_{2}\left(>t_{1}\right)$. When this motion is viewed from another inertial system moving in the $x$-direction at a relative velocity $v$ to the original one, it follows a Lorentz transformation to a new coordinates $\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$. The time

difference $t_{2}-t_{1}$ between $A$ and $B$ is Lorentz transformed to

$$
t_{2}^{\prime}-t_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(v / c)^{2}}}\left[t_{2}-t_{1}-\frac{v}{c^{2}}\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)\right]
$$

For events on the spacelike path, the Lorentz transformation does not leave the temporal order invariant. When the fermion has a small velocity, the observer has more options of a large or small relative velocity $v$ to the fermion. A sufficiently large spacelike interval between two events, such as $c\left(t_{2}-t_{1}\right)<(v / c)\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)$ in Eq.(4), reverses the temporal order of two events, $t_{2}^{\prime}<t_{1}^{\prime}$ as shown in Figure.2(b). The natural interpretation of such situations is that a positively-charged antifermion runs in the opposite spatial direction without the reversal of temporal order. Hence, either an annihilation of massless fermion in Figure.2(a), or a creation of massless antifermion in Figure.2(b) is observed at $A$, according to the choice of inertial frame that the observer sits on.

When the virtual many-body state is formulated, antifermion should be used so that the time direction in every particle is not reversed even if it is viewed by any observer [14]. Momentum, electric charge and spin, which prescribe all properties of massless fermion, are not positive definite, and therefore the effect of annihilation operator $a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})$ on the state in Figure.2(a) is equivalent to that of creation operator $b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ on the state in Figure.2(b). To derive the state ensuring this equivalence, a new operator $\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})$ is defined so as to derive such a state as its eigenstate,

$$
\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})=\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})+\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p})
$$

If the fermion is massive, the creation and annihilation cause different effects on the state because mass is positive definite, and their superposition is impossible. Hence, this superposition is possible only for the massless fermion in the primitive world. The necessity of antifermion changes according to the relative velocity between the incident particle and the observer, which is reflected in $\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}$. When $\boldsymbol{p}=0$, the difference between $a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})$ and $b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ in momentum vanishes. Therefore, the number of observers for whom the process of Figure.2(a) and (b) have the same probability increases as $\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow 0$, resulting in $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}=\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}$ at $\boldsymbol{p}=0$. On the contrary, when $\boldsymbol{p}^{2} \rightarrow \infty$, such observers cannot be found, and antifermion is not needed. Hence, $\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} \rightarrow 0$ is expected.

The same interpretation is possible also for the event at $B$ in Figure.2. Another new operator $\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ is defined as a superposition of the annihilation $b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ of massless antifermion

in Figure.2(b), and the creation $a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})$ of massless fermion in 2(a)

$$
\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})=\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})-\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})
$$

This $\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ is orthogonal to $\widetilde{a}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ [15]. These $\widetilde{a}^{s}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}\right)$ and $\widetilde{b}^{s}\left(-\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}\right)$ are useful not only for the two-body state, but also for general many-body states. Among various virtual many-body states, these superposed operators define the lowest-energy one $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ by imposing $\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$ on it. This lowest-energy state implies physical vacuum.

# III. MASSIVE FERMIONS AND ANTIFERMIONS IN PHYSICAL VACUUM 

The explicit form of $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is inferred as follows. In the case of massless fermions moving as fast as light, relative velocity between two different observers has no meaning in practice, so that $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} \rightarrow 1$ is required in Eqs.(5) and (6), and the physical vacuum agrees with the Fock vacuum. Therefore $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ should include $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}|0\rangle$. Conversely, in the case of fermion with small momentum, relative velocity between observers has a meaning, and the number of observers with large relative velocity $v$ such as leading to $t_{2}^{\prime}-t_{1}^{\prime}<0$ in Eq.(4) increases as $\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow 0$. In such a case, not only massless fermions with $\boldsymbol{p}$ but also antifermions with $-\boldsymbol{p}$ is necessary, and they should coexist in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ as $b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})|0\rangle$. The simplest possible form of $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ including these two cases is a superpositions of $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}|0\rangle$ and $\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})|0\rangle$. The lowest-energy state $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is a direct product of such superpositions for all $\boldsymbol{p}$ (see Appendix.A)

$$
|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\prod_{p, s}\left[\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}+\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} e^{i \alpha(x)} b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})\right]|0\rangle
$$

A phase factor $\exp [\alpha(x)]$ concerning $U(1)$ symmetry appears at each point in space-time [16]. This $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ contains many moving virtual massless particles, but it is not characterized by any specific momentum. Hence, the relativistic normalization is not needed [17].

The superposition in Eq.(7) implies that massless pairs incessantly appear and disappear. In this sense, the physical vacuum is not a quiet vacuum. This $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ was first introduced to elementary-particle physics by [18] in analogy with superconductivity [19]. However, it is not a specific form affected by this analogy, but a general form that we think of first as a deviation from the simple Fock vacuum. In superconductivity, the momentum of electrons in metals represents the relative motion of electrons to the center-of-mass of crystal. The naive analogy such as the center-of-mass of world cannot be carried over into the physical

vacuum, because the only momentum that has meaning is the momentum of relative motion between an observer and a particle. The derivation of the physical vacuum via Eqs.(5) and (6), which uses such a relative momentum, is a natural way to describe vacuum.

In the BEH model, for deriving the broken-symmetry vacuum, a phenomenological treatment such as the switch of sign of $\mu^{2}$ in the Higgs potential was needed. In contrast, the argument on the origin of Eq.(7) is grounded on the time direction in the relativistic virtual many-body system. The broken-symmetry vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ has a kinematical origin, but some dynamical consequences follow from it. The common direction of time from past to future achieved here enables us to describe the dynamics in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$.

In the physical vacuum, massless fermions and antifermions will have various interactions via $B_{\mu}$. If we consider the symmetry-broken vacuum as a direct analogue of superconductivity, we should consider an attractive interaction to cause symmetry breaking. However, since the physical vacuum in Eq.(7) arises from kinematical breaking of symmetry, it is freed from the role of causing symmetry breaking. Therefore, whatever effective interaction acts on a massless fermion, regardless of being repulsive or attractive, it induces the motion of other fermions, which turns out to be an inertial mass of the original fermion. We assume that the mean-field approximation is effective also in the relativistic many-body problem, and regard a constant $U_{0}$ as a mean field without specifying its origin,

$$
\bar{\varphi}(x)\left(i \not \partial+U_{0}\right) \varphi(x)
$$

The physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is a stable state with the lowest-energy. Hence, if Eq.(8) is sandwiched between $\langle\widetilde{0}|$ and $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$, it is diagonal with respect to $\widetilde{a}^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) \widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})$ and $\widetilde{b}^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) \widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ for all $\boldsymbol{p}$. Following the same procedure as in [19], we obtain the reverse relation of Eqs.(5) and (6), and after substituting them to $\varphi(x)$ in Eq.(8), we impose the condition that Eq.(8) is diagonal, with the result that

$$
\cos ^{2} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{\epsilon_{p}}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{p}^{2}+U_{0}^{2}}}\right), \quad \sin ^{2} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{\epsilon_{p}}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{p}^{2}+U_{0}^{2}}}\right)
$$

The diagonalized form of Eq.(8) includes $\sqrt{\epsilon_{p}^{2}+U_{0}^{2}}\left[\widetilde{a}^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) \widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})+\widetilde{b}^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) \widetilde{b}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})\right]$, in which $U_{0}^{2}$ represents a square of the mass $m_{f}^{2}$ of the fermion and antifermion. This condition satisfies $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}=\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}$ at $\boldsymbol{p}=0$, and $\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}} \rightarrow 0$ at $\boldsymbol{p} \rightarrow \infty$, which satisfy conditions we expected for the kinematical relation (5) and (6).

# IV. THE BEHAVIOR AS QUASI BOSONS 

In the BEH model, the vacuum condensate $v_{h}$ in $L_{h}(x)$ implies the rigidity of vacuum. This rigidity should be physically explained by the virtual massless fermion and antifermion in the vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ of Eq.(7). It is always as a pair that they appear and disappear in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ with opposite direction of momentum and spin. Their fields should virtually overlap in position space for short time period, and we represent their behavior by dimensionless complex operators $P_{\boldsymbol{k}} \equiv b(-\boldsymbol{k}, \downarrow) a(\boldsymbol{k}, \uparrow)$ and $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{\dagger} \equiv a^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{k}, \uparrow) b^{\dagger}(-\boldsymbol{k}, \downarrow) . \quad(\uparrow, \downarrow$ denote spins.) Owing to the anti-commutation relation of $a(\boldsymbol{k}, \uparrow)$ and $b(-\boldsymbol{k}, \downarrow)$, the complex operator $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ has a following equal-time commutation relation at $\boldsymbol{k} \neq \boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}$

$$
\left[P_{\boldsymbol{k}}, P_{\boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}}^{\dagger}\right]=0 \quad \text { for } \quad \boldsymbol{k} \neq \boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}
$$

but when $\boldsymbol{k}=\boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}$, due to Pauli principle, $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ shows a following commutation relation

$$
\left[P_{\boldsymbol{k}}, P_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{\dagger}\right]=1-\left(n_{\boldsymbol{k}, \uparrow}+n_{-\boldsymbol{k}, \downarrow}\right), \quad P_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{2}=P_{\boldsymbol{k}}^{\dagger 2}=0
$$

These commutation relations show that the pair denoted by $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ behaves as a quasi bosons.
Figure 3 schematically illustrates, using small white circles, the distribution of these quasi bosons in position space at a certain moment, and shows that the gauge field $B_{\mu}$ propagates along the horizontal line. The behavior of virtual bosons is a limited one in the temporal and spatial sense. Here we define a coherence length $l_{c}$ of vacuum such that as long as the distance between these quasi bosons is less than $l_{c}$, they obey Bose statistics. They appear and disappear randomly in position space, but we consider for simplicity a mean distance between quasi bosons $d_{m}$. Consider a following complex field of quasi bosons made of $\varphi(x)$ in Eq.(3)

$$
f(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{V}} \sum_{k, s}\left[P_{\boldsymbol{k}} \bar{v}^{s}(-k) u^{s}(k)+P_{-\boldsymbol{k}}^{\dagger} \bar{u}^{s}(-k) v^{s}(k)\right] e^{i k x}
$$

(The normalization volume $V$ in $\varphi(x)$ of Eq.(3) and $f(x)$ is $d_{m}^{3}$.) This $f(x)$ describes the excitations within the coherence length. Their excitation has a following kinetic energy

$$
H_{e f}=\int\left|\frac{\partial}{\partial x} f(x)\right|^{2} d^{3} x=-\int f^{\dagger}(x) \Delta f(x) d^{3} x
$$

Consider the kinetic energy of quasi bosons when the gauge field $B_{\mu}$ in Figure 3(a) move quasi bosons on the solid horizontal line to those on a dotted wavy line. Bose statistics

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

FIG. 3. A schematic view of the physical vacuum at a certain moment in position space. Each white circle represents a quasi-boson, which is distributed with a mean distance $d_{m}$. (a) The transverse displacements $(d r)$ of quasi bosons from the horizontal line ( $z$ axis), coupled to the propagating gauge field $B_{\mu}$ along the $z$ axis, and (b) the longitudinal displacements $(d z)$ are illustrated.
requires that permutation symmetry holds for quasi bosons. A long white arrow from horizontal line to black circles in Figure 3(a) is undistinguishable from small arrows between neighboring white circles and black ones due to Bose statistics. When a long displacement appears in the denominator of Laplacian operator $\Delta$ in Eq.(13), it is undistinguishable from a short displacement. Because the transverse displacements are not additive, there are many short displacements after excitation, and this indistinguishability is evident especially for the transverse displacement of pairs. (In contrast, since the longitudinal displacement is additive as shown in Figure 3(b), the long displacements are dominant, and the short displacements are exceptional.) The short distance in the denominator of Laplacian operator $\Delta$ in Eq.(13) creates a high excitation energy, and an energy gap $\epsilon_{0}$ from zero appears in the transverse excitation spectrum. This energy gap comes only from statistical property, and we call it statistical gap [20].

This situation is expressed using a shrinkable position space. For the transverse direction, the quasi-bosons are placed as if they are in a shrinkable space represented by a metric tensor $g_{i j}(x)$ in differential geometry. For the transverse and longitudinal distances $r$ and $z$ in Figure

3, it is expressed as $d l^{2}=g_{r r}(r) d r^{2}+d z^{2}$ for $r<l_{c}$. When the quasi bosons in Figure 3(a) move within the coherent space-time region with a size $l_{c}$, a simple metric representing the situation is given by

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
g_{r r}(r)=\frac{d_{m}^{2}}{r^{2}}, & \left(d_{m} \leq r<l_{c}\right) \\
g_{r r}(r)=1, & \left(0<r<d_{m}, \quad l_{c} \leq r\right)
\end{array}
$$

The gradient in the shrinkable space in Eq.(13) is rewritten as follows (see Appendix.B)

$$
H_{e f}=\int g_{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial \widehat{f^{\dagger}}}{\partial x^{\mu}} \frac{\partial \widehat{f}}{\partial x^{\nu}} d^{3} x+\int W(x) \widehat{f^{\dagger}}(x) \widehat{f}(x) d^{3} x
$$

where a normalized field $\widehat{f}(x) \equiv g(x)^{1 / 4} f(x)$ has, in addition to the kinetic energy, the square of the finite energy gap $\epsilon_{0}$ as $W(x)(\mu, \nu=x, y, z)[21]$

$$
W(x)=\frac{1}{4} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\mu}}\left(g_{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right)+\frac{1}{16} g_{\mu \nu}\left(\frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\mu}}\right)\left(\frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right)
$$

Using Eq.(14) in Eq.(16), $W(r)$ of each particle is given by

$$
W(r)=\frac{3}{2} \frac{d_{m}^{2}}{r^{4}}+\frac{1}{4} \frac{d_{m}^{2}}{r^{4}}
$$

and the square of $\epsilon_{0}$ averaged over the coherent space-time region $\left(d_{m}<r<l_{c}\right)$ is given by

$$
\epsilon_{0}^{2}=\frac{1}{d_{m}} \int_{d_{m}}^{l_{c}} W(r) d r=\frac{7}{12} \frac{1}{d_{m}^{2}}\left[1-\left(\frac{d_{m}}{l_{c}}\right)^{3}\right]
$$

Owing to this gap $\epsilon_{0}$, the eigenstate of $\widehat{f}(x)$ remains in the ground state even under strong transverse perturbations, exhibiting a kind of rigidity of the physical vacuum. This rigidity implies $\langle\widetilde{0}| \partial_{\mu} \widehat{f}(x)|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$ in the transverse perturbation within the coherent space-time region. Hence, the eigenstate of $\varphi(x)$ composing $f(x)$ in Eq.(12) also remains in the ground state with a flat spatial distriution, thus leading to $\langle\widetilde{0}| \partial_{\mu}\left[\bar{\varphi}(x) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi(x)\right]|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$. This is the origin of the vacuum condensate $v_{h}$ in $\left|\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right)\left(v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right)\right|^{2}$ of $L_{h}(x)$ in Eq.(1).

# V. MASSIVE GAUGE BOSON 

In the BEH model, the mass of gauge boson is derived from the phenomenological coupling $\left|\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right)\left(v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right)\right|^{2}$ as $m_{B}^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu}=g^{2} v_{h}^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu}$. Instead of this, we begin with a simple Lagrangian density $L_{0}(x)$ and the physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$. The physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is

not a simple system, and therefore the response of $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ to $B_{\mu}$ gives rise to a non-linear effect. The minimal coupling to fermions $L_{0}^{\min }(x)=\bar{\varphi}(x)\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi(x)$ changes its form due to the perturbation of $\mathcal{H}_{I}(x)=g j^{\mu}(x) B_{\mu}(x)$ to $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ [22]. Consider a perturbation expansion of $\int d^{4} x L_{0}^{\min }(x)$ in powers of $g$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} L_{0}^{\min }\left(x_{1}\right) e x p\left(i \int \mathcal{H}_{I}\left(x_{2}\right) d^{4} x_{2}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle \\
& \quad=\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} \bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma^{\mu}\left[i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right)\right] \varphi\left(x_{1}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle \\
& \quad+\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} \bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma^{\mu}\left[i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right)\right] \varphi\left(x_{1}\right) i g \int d^{4} x_{2} j^{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right) B_{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle+\cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

(1) In the last term of Eq.(19), $B_{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right)$ couples to $B_{\nu}\left(x_{1}\right)$, yielding the following two-point-correlation function between $\bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi\left(x_{1}\right)$ and $\bar{\varphi}\left(x_{2}\right) \gamma^{\nu} \varphi\left(x_{2}\right)$

$$
\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} \mathcal{H}_{I}\left(x_{1}\right) \int d^{4} x_{2} \mathcal{H}_{I}\left(x_{2}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

Because the gauge field is a transverse one, the excitation induced by this $B_{\mu}(x)$ is a transverse one as well. Since these $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are separated microscopically, an observer at a distant space-time point from it regard it as a local phenomenon at $X=\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right) / 2$. For such an observer, it is useful to rewrite $d^{4} x_{1} d^{4} x_{2}$ in Eq.(20) as $d^{4} X d^{4} Y$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& g^{2} \int\langle\widetilde{0}| \int j_{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right) d^{2} x_{1} \int j^{\mu}\left(x_{2}\right) d^{2} x_{2}|\widetilde{0}\rangle B^{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right) B_{\mu}\left(x_{2}\right) d^{2} x_{1} d^{2} x_{2} \\
= & g^{2} \int\langle\widetilde{0}| \int j_{\mu}(Y) j^{\mu}(0) d^{4} Y|\widetilde{0}\rangle \times B^{\mu}(X) B_{\mu}(X) d^{4} X \\
\equiv & M^{2} \int B^{\mu}(X) B_{\mu}(X) d^{4} X
\end{aligned}
$$

The relative motion along $Y=x_{2}-x_{1}$ is indirectly observed as a following constant $M$ for $\mu=\nu$,

$$
M^{2}=g^{2}\langle\widetilde{0}| \int j_{\mu}(Y) j^{\mu}(0) d^{4} Y|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

(2) The correlation of currents in Eq.(22) is strongly influenced by permutation symmetry of Bose statistics. Within the coherent region $Z_{c}$, the physical vacuum is rigid and remains in the ground state, and $\langle\widetilde{0}| \partial_{\mu}[\bar{\varphi}(Y) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi(Y)]|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$ holds for the transverse component of $Y$, and the correlation of currents in Eq.(22) is reduced to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\widetilde{0}| j_{\mu}(Y) j^{\mu}(0)|\widetilde{0}\rangle & =\langle\widetilde{0}|\left(j_{\mu}(0)+\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial Y_{\mu}}\left[\bar{\varphi}(Y) \gamma_{\mu} \varphi(Y)\right]\right]_{Y_{\mu}=0} Y^{\mu}+\cdots\right) j^{\mu}(0)|\widetilde{0}\rangle \\
& \Rightarrow\langle\widetilde{0}| j_{\mu}(0) j^{\mu}(0)|\widetilde{0}\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

FIG. 4. The coherent space-time region is a small cone specified by $l_{c}$ at the bottom of the light cone (a shaded area). (a) The gauge boson $B_{\mu}$ (a wavy line) induces vacuum polarization only outside the coherent space-time region. (b) The Higgs field $H(x)$ (black circles) induces vacuum polarization both inside and outside the coherent space-time region.

With Eq.(23), $M^{2}$ in Eq.(22) is identified as the gauge boson's mass $m_{B}^{2}$. Using $j^{\mu}(0)=$ $\left(\varphi^{\dagger} \varphi, i \varphi^{\dagger} \gamma^{0} \gamma \varphi\right)$, we obtain $\langle\widetilde{0}| j_{\mu}(0) j^{\mu}(0)|\widetilde{0}\rangle=2\langle\widetilde{0}|\left[\varphi^{\dagger}(0) \varphi(0)\right]^{2}|\widetilde{0}\rangle$. The $m_{B}^{2}$ in Eq.(22) is given by

$$
m_{B}^{2}=2 g^{2}\langle\widetilde{0}| \int_{Y \in 2 Z_{c}}\left[\varphi^{\dagger}(0) \varphi(0)\right]^{2} d^{4} Y|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

The coherent space-time region $Z_{c}$ is a small cone at the bottom of the light cone as illustrated in Figure 4 for one spatial direction. Its space length is less than $l_{c}$, and time width is smaller than $l_{c} / c$, so that the causal relation is possible between two spatial ends separated by $l_{c}$. (The life time of virtual massless pair of fermion and antifermion in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is related to $l_{c} / c$.) The volume of coherent space-time region $\int_{Y \in Z_{c}} d^{4} Y=l_{c}^{2} \times \frac{1}{2}\left[l_{c} \times c\left(l_{c} / c\right)\right] \times 2=l_{c}^{4}$ in Figure 4 is Lorentz invariant. Since the vacuum is rigid in $Z_{c}$, the vacuum polarization induced by $B_{\mu}$ occurs only outside of this region as shown in Figure 4(a).

In Eq.(24), the normalization volume $V$ of $\varphi(x)$ in Eq.(3) is $V_{c}=d_{m}^{3}$. Every fermion and antifermion in $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ make the same contribution to $\langle\widetilde{0}|\left[\varphi^{\dagger}(0) \varphi(0)\right]^{2}|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\widetilde{0}|\left[\varphi^{\dagger}(0) \varphi(0)\right]^{2}|\widetilde{0}\rangle & =\langle\widetilde{0}| \frac{1}{d_{m}^{6}} \sum_{p, s}\left(\left[a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) u^{s \dagger}(p)+b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p}) v^{s \dagger}(-p)\right]\left[a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) u^{s}(p)+b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) v^{s}(-p)\right]\right)^{2}|\widetilde{0}\rangle\right. \\
& =\frac{1}{d_{m}^{6}} \prod_{p, s}\left(\sin ^{2} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}+\cos ^{2} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{d_{m}^{6}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for the 4-dimensional volume $l_{c}^{4}$ of the region $Z_{c}$, we obtain

$$
m_{B}^{2}=2 g^{2} \frac{1}{d_{m}^{6}} \int_{Y \in 2 Z_{c}} d^{4} Y=g^{2}\left(\frac{2 l_{c}^{2}}{d_{m}^{3}}\right)^{2}
$$

This $2 l_{c}^{2} / d_{m}^{3}$ is the content of vacuum condensate $v_{h}$, which is phenomenologically assumed as $m_{B}^{2}=g^{2} v_{h}^{2}$ in the BEH model.
(3) The Goldstone mode exists in the last term of Eq.(19). For the first-order term of $B_{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right)$, integrate $\bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) i \partial^{\mu} \gamma_{\mu} \varphi\left(x_{1}\right)$ over $x_{1}$ by parts, and use the fact that $\varphi\left(x_{1}\right)$ vanishes at $x_{1} \rightarrow \infty$. As a result, we obtain two types of terms, one including $i \partial^{\mu} \bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma_{\mu} \varphi\left(x_{1}\right)$, and the other including $\partial^{\mu}|\widetilde{0}\rangle$. The latter is given by

$$
g\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} j_{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right) \int d^{4} x_{2} j^{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right) B_{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right) \partial^{\mu}|\widetilde{0}\rangle+g \partial^{\mu}\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} j_{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right) \int d^{4} x_{2} j^{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right) B_{\nu}\left(x_{2}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

Because the physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ in Eq.(7) has an explicit $x$-dependence in the phase $\alpha(x)$, $\partial^{\mu}|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ contains $\partial^{\mu} \alpha(x)$. The distant observer regards Eq.(27) as a local phenomenon at $X$, and rewrites it using $d^{4} x_{1} d^{4} x_{2}=d^{4} X d^{4} Y$ as

$$
\frac{2 i}{g} m_{B}^{2} \int B_{\mu}(X) \partial^{\mu} \alpha(X) d^{4} X \equiv m_{B} \int B_{\mu}(X) \partial^{\mu} G(X) d^{4} X
$$

Here the Goldstone mode is defined as $G(X)=2 i g^{-1} m_{B} \alpha(X)$. (In the BEH model, the coupling of the Goldstone mode $h_{2}$ to the gauge boson is derived from the phenomenological term $\left|\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right)\left(v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right)\right|^{2}$. Equation.(28) shows that this coupling has an origin in the response of the physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ to $B_{\mu}$.)
(4) In the system without the long-range force, the global phase-rotation of fermion's field requires no energy, and therefore the propagator of the Goldstone mode is given by

$$
\int \frac{d X^{4}}{(2 \pi)^{4}}\langle\widetilde{0}| T[G(X) G(0)]|\widetilde{0}\rangle e^{i q X}=\frac{i}{q^{2}}
$$

However, the long-range force mediated by the gauge boson prohibits a free rotation of the global phase $\alpha(x)$, then preventing the Goldstone mode. This discrepancy is solved by the generation of the gauge-boson's mass that converts the long-range force into a shortrange one. The Fourier transform of Eqs.(21) and (28) are given by $m_{B}^{2} B^{\mu}(q) B_{\mu}(q)$ and $m_{B} q^{\mu} G(q) B_{\mu}(q)$, respectively. Following the usual way, regard the latter as a perturbation to the former, and the second-order perturbation is obtained as

$$
B^{\mu}(q)\left[i m_{B}^{2} g^{\mu \nu}-m_{B} q^{\mu} \frac{i}{q^{2}} m_{B} q^{\nu}\right] B_{\nu}(q)=i m_{B}^{2}\left(g^{\mu \nu}-\frac{q^{\mu} q^{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right) B^{\mu}(q) B^{\nu}(q)
$$

Adding Eq.(30) to the Fourier transform of $-\frac{1}{4} F^{\mu \nu} F_{\mu \nu}$, and performing an inverse transformation on the resulting matrix, we obtain

$$
D^{\mu \nu}(q)=\frac{-i}{q^{2}-m_{B}^{2}}\left(g^{\mu \nu}-\frac{q^{\mu} q^{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right) \equiv i D\left(q^{2}\right)\left(g^{\mu \nu}-\frac{q^{\mu} q^{\nu}}{q^{2}}\right)
$$

which is the propagator of the massive gauge boson in the Landau gauge. Spontaneous gauge-symmetry breaking comes from the rigidity of the physical vacuum in the transverse perturbation. Additional terms to $L_{0}(x)$ necessary for this phenomenon are $m_{B}^{2} B^{\mu}(q) B_{\mu}(q)$, $m_{B} B_{\mu}(x) \partial^{\mu} G(x)$ and $\left(\partial_{\mu} G(x)\right)^{2}$.
(5) In the BEH model, the coupling of the Goldstone mode to fermions comes explicitly from the Yukawa interaction. In the present model, such a coupling is included implicitly in the first term in the right-hand side of Eq.(19). For the zeroth-order term of $B_{\mu}$, the integration over $x_{1}$ by parts yields two types of terms, one including $i \partial^{\mu} \bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma_{\mu} \varphi\left(x_{1}\right)$, and the other including $\partial^{\mu} \mid \widetilde{0}\rangle$. The latter term is given by

$$
i\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} j^{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right) \partial_{\mu}|\widetilde{0}\rangle+i \partial_{\mu}\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} j^{\mu}\left(x_{1}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

Since $\partial_{\mu}|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\partial_{\mu} \alpha(x)|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ contains the Goldstone mode $G(x)=2 i g^{-1} m_{B} \alpha(x)$, Eq.(32) gives the coupling of the Goldstone mode $G$ to fermion

$$
\frac{g}{m_{B}}\langle\widetilde{0}| \int d^{4} x_{1} \bar{\varphi}\left(x_{1}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi\left(x_{1}\right) \partial_{\mu} G\left(x_{1}\right)|\widetilde{0}\rangle
$$

As a result, $\left(g / m_{B}\right) \bar{\varphi}(x) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi(x) \partial_{\mu} G(x)$ appear in the Lagrangian density, which is different from $g\left(m_{f} / m_{B}\right) \bar{\varphi}(x) \varphi(x) h_{2}(x)$ in the BEH model.

# VI. HIGGS PARTICLE 

In the BEH model, $-\mu^{2}|h|^{2}$ in $L_{h}(x)$ of Eq.(1) plays double roles. The first is the generation of the broken-symmetry vacuum by switching the sign of $\mu^{2}$. The second is giving the Higgs particle a mass $m_{H}$. However, the former is concerned with the global property of the world, and the latter is concerned with the property of one particle. It seems strange that such different scale of things are described by the same parameter. In the present model, the symmetry breaking of vacuum has the kinematical origin, and the mass of Higgs particle comes from an interaction in which fermions are involved.

Under general type of external perturbations to the system, the constant effective interaction $U_{0}$ in Eq.(8) changes to dynamic one as $U_{0}+U_{1}(x)$. In this case, Eq.(8) changes to

$$
\bar{\varphi}(x)\left[i \not \partial+U_{0}+U_{1}(x)\right] \varphi(x)
$$

We normalize $U_{1}(x)$ as $U_{1}(x) / U_{0}=U_{1}(x) / m_{f}$. If we assume that the dynamic interaction $U_{1}(x)$ is mediated by an excitation mode $H(x)$ as

$$
H(x) \equiv \frac{m_{B}}{g} \frac{U_{1}(x)}{m_{f}}
$$

Eq.(34) is rewritten as

$$
\bar{\varphi}(x)\left[i \not \partial+U_{0}+\widehat{g} H(x)\right] \varphi(x)
$$

where $\widehat{g}$ is given by

$$
\widehat{g}=\frac{m_{f}}{m_{B}} g
$$

Owing to the relation $m_{B}=g v_{h}$ in the BEH model, this $\widehat{g}$ is $m_{f} / v_{h}$, which agrees with the coupling constant of the Higgs particle to fermions in the BEH model. Hence, $H(x)$ in Eq.(35) can be regarded as the Higgs field.

This $H(x)$ is an excitation of fermions and antifermions. It propagates in space through a chain of creations and annihilations of massless fermion-antifermion pairs as shown in Figure 4(b), in which black circles linking bubbles represent $H(x)$. Because this excitation is isotropic in space, it is represented by a scalar field. This implies that the induced excitation of fermion and antifermion is not transverse, and its excitation has no energy gap. Here we define an upper end $\Lambda$ of energy-momentum of the excited massive fermion-antifermion pairs. The self energy of the Higgs field $H(x)$ is given by

$$
i q^{2} \chi\left(q^{2}\right)=\left(-i \widehat{g}^{2}\right)^{2}(-1) \int_{0}^{\Lambda} \frac{d^{4} p}{(2 \pi)^{4}} t r\left[\frac{i}{p-m_{f}} \frac{i}{p+p_{-} m_{f}}-m_{f}\right]
$$

in which $\gamma^{\mu}$ matrix is not there [23]. The integral over $p$ in Eq.(38) is taken from zero to this $\Lambda$. According to the ordinary rule, we use a new variable $l=p+x q$. The upper end in the integral over $l$ is $\sqrt{p^{2}+2 x p \cdot q+x^{2} q^{2}}$, which depends on the relative direction of $p$ to $q$. Since the sign of $p \cdot q$ oscillates between positive and negative, we use a mean value $\sqrt{p^{2}+x^{2} q^{2}}$ for simplicity. Hence, using an Euclidian 4-momentum $l_{E}$ as $l^{2}=-l_{E}^{2}$, we obtain

$$
q^{2} \chi\left(q^{2}\right)=-4 \widehat{g}^{4} \int_{0}^{1} d x \int \frac{d \Omega_{4}}{(2 \pi)^{4}} \int_{\sqrt{x^{2} q^{2}}}^{\sqrt{\Lambda^{2}+x^{2} q^{2}}} l_{E}^{2} d l_{E}\left[\frac{-l_{E}^{2}}{\left(l_{E}^{2}+\Delta\right)^{2}}+\frac{\Delta}{\left(l_{E}^{2}+\Delta\right)^{2}}\right]
$$

where $\Delta=m_{f}^{2}-x(1-x) q^{2}$. If we define a following integral

$$
I(m, n) \equiv \int l_{E}^{m}\left(l_{E}^{2}+\Delta\right)^{n} d l_{E}
$$

the indefinite integrals over $l_{E}$ in Eq.(39) are decomposed as follows

$$
I(5,-2)-\Delta \times I(3,-2)=I(1,0)-3 \Delta \times I(1,-1)+2 \Delta^{2} \times I(1,-2)
$$

where

$$
I(1,0)=\frac{1}{2} l_{E}^{2}, \quad I(1,-1)=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left|l_{E}^{2}+\Delta\right|, \quad I(1,-2)=-\frac{1}{2\left(l_{E}^{2}+\Delta\right)}
$$

The definite integral over $l_{E}$ in Eq.(39) yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
q^{2} \chi\left(q^{2}\right)=\frac{\widehat{g}^{4}}{4 \pi^{2}} \Lambda^{2} & -\frac{\widehat{g}^{4}}{2 \pi^{2}} \int_{0}^{1} d x \Delta^{2}\left(\frac{1}{\Lambda^{2}+x^{2} q^{2}+\Delta}-\frac{1}{x^{2} q^{2}+\Delta}\right) \\
& -\frac{\widehat{g}^{4}}{2 \pi^{2}} \int_{0}^{1} d x \frac{3}{2} \Delta \ln \left|1+\frac{\Lambda^{2}}{x^{2} q^{2}+\Delta}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

With this $\chi\left(q^{2}\right)$, the propagator of the Higgs excitation mode $H(x)$ is given by

$$
\int \frac{d^{4} x}{(2 \pi)^{4}}\langle\widetilde{0}| T[H(x) H(0)]|\widetilde{0}\rangle e^{i q x}=\frac{1}{q^{2}\left[1-\chi\left(q^{2}\right)\right]}
$$

The mass $m_{H}$ of the Higgs particle is defined as $\chi\left(q^{2}\right) \simeq m_{H}^{2} / q^{2}$ at $q^{2} \rightarrow 0$. Since $\Delta \rightarrow m_{f}^{2}$ at $q^{2} \rightarrow 0$, the integrals over $x$ in the second and third terms of the right-hand side of Eq.(43) have following limits at $q^{2} \rightarrow 0$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int_{0}^{1} d x \frac{1}{\Lambda^{2}+x^{2} q^{2}+\Delta} \rightarrow \frac{3}{4\left(\Lambda^{2}+m_{f}^{2}\right)} \\
\int_{0}^{1} d x \ln \left|1+\frac{\Lambda^{2}}{x^{2} q^{2}+\Delta}\right| \rightarrow \ln \left|\frac{\lambda^{2}+m_{f}^{2}}{m_{f}^{2}}\right|
\end{gathered}
$$

. Plugging Eqs.(45) and (46) into Eq.(43), and using it in Eq.(44), the mass $m_{H}$ is given by

$$
m_{H}^{2}=\frac{\widehat{g}^{4}}{4 \pi^{2}}\left[\Lambda^{2}+\frac{3}{2} m_{f}^{2}\left(1-\frac{m_{f}^{2}}{\Lambda^{2}+m_{f}^{2}}\right)-3 m_{f}^{2} \ln \left(\frac{\Lambda^{2}+m_{f}^{2}}{m_{f}^{2}}\right)\right]
$$

The Higgs mass is determined by $\Lambda, m_{f}$, and $m_{B}$ in $\widehat{g}$.
The Higgs excitation is described by the following effective Lagrangian density

$$
\left(\partial_{\mu} H\right)^{2}-m_{H}^{2} H^{2}+\frac{m_{f}}{m_{B}} g \bar{\varphi} \varphi H
$$

The reason why the mass of the Higgs particle has been an unknown parameter in the electroweak theory using the BEH mechanism is that it is not a quantity inferred from symmetry, but a result of the many-body phenomenon.

# VII. DISCUSSION 

In summary, the phenomena in the physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ is described by the following total Lagrangian density $\widetilde{L}(x)$. After rewriting $\varphi$ and $\bar{\varphi}$ with $\psi$ and $\bar{\psi}, \widetilde{L}(x)$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{L}(x)= & -\frac{1}{4} F^{\mu \nu} F_{\mu \nu}+m_{B}^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu}+\bar{\psi}\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \psi-m_{f} \bar{\psi} \psi \\
& +\left(\partial_{\mu} G\right)^{2}+m_{B} B_{\mu} \partial^{\mu} G+\frac{g}{m_{B}} \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \psi \partial_{\mu} G \\
& +\left(\partial_{\mu} H\right)^{2}-m_{H}^{2} H^{2}+\frac{m_{f}}{m_{B}} g \bar{\psi} \psi H
\end{aligned}
$$

This $\widetilde{L}(x)$ has an explicit physical meaning. The double role of the Higgs potential mentioned in Section. 1 is dissolved. The broken-symmetry vacuum is derived from the kinematical breaking. The vacuum condensate $v_{h}$ is explained by the statistical gap in the transverse excitation. The Higgs particle's mass is the result of the many-body phenomenon, and the fermion's mass is determined without the vacuum condensate of Higgs field. Each role of the Higgs potential is played by each physical process, and the parameters $\mu, \lambda$ and $m_{f}$ in $L_{h}(x)$ of Eq.(1) have the following physical interpretations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mu^{2}}{2 \lambda}=\left(\frac{2 l_{c}^{2}}{d_{m}^{3}}\right)^{2}, \quad\left(=v_{h}^{2}\right) \\
& 2 \mu^{2}=\frac{\tilde{g}^{4}}{4 \pi^{2}}\left[\Lambda^{2}+\frac{3}{2} U_{0}^{2}\left(1-\frac{U_{0}^{2}}{\Lambda^{2}+U_{0}^{2}}\right)-3 U_{0}^{2} \ln \left(1+\frac{\Lambda^{2}}{U_{0}^{2}}\right)\right], \quad\left(=m_{H}^{2}\right) \\
& m_{f}=U_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Compared to $L_{0}(x)+L_{h}(x)$ of the BEH model, this $\widetilde{L}(x)$ has the following features.
(1) In the BEH model, $\left|\left(i \partial_{\mu}+g B_{\mu}\right)\left(v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right)\right|^{2}$ predicts direct couplings of the Higgs particle $h_{1}$ and Goldstone mode $h_{2}$ to the massive gauge boson such as

$$
g^{2} v_{h}^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu}\left(1+\frac{h_{1}}{v_{h}}\right)^{2}+g^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu} h_{2}^{2}+2 g B^{\mu}\left(h_{1} \partial_{\mu} h_{2}+h_{2} \partial_{\mu} h_{1}\right)+(c . c)
$$

However, the Higgs-like excitation $H$ is not an elementary field, so that gauge coupling term of $H$ with the same coupling constant $g$ does not exist. Instead of $m_{B}^{2} B^{\mu} B_{\mu}\left(1+h_{1} / v_{h}\right)^{2}$, the effective coupling of $H$ to $B_{\mu}$ arises from the perturbative process through $\bar{\psi}$ and $\psi$ of $\widehat{g} \bar{\psi} \psi H$ and $g \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \psi B_{\mu}$, which gives different predictions from the BEH model.
(2) One of the important prediction by the Yukawa interaction $\left(m_{f} / v_{h}\right)\left(v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right) \bar{\varphi} \varphi$ in the BEH model is that the strength of the Higgs's coupling to fermions is proportional to the fermion's mass, which is confirmed by experiments in the electroweak interaction. The

above $\widetilde{L}(x)$ also possesses this feature in $\left(m_{f} / m_{B}\right) g \bar{\psi} \psi H$. Unlike the Yukawa interaction, however, this term does not give the coupling of the Goldstone mode $G$ to the fermion. Rather, such a coupling $\left(g / m_{B}\right) \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \psi \partial_{\mu} G$ in $\widetilde{L}(x)$ arises from the structure of the physical vacuum as seen in Eqs.(32) and (33).

The present model has implications for some fundamental problems in the BEH model.
(a) The present model proposes a solution to the fine-tuning problem of the quadratic divergence. Since it does not assume the Higgs potential $-4 \lambda v_{h} h_{1}^{3}-\lambda h_{1}^{4}$, the quadratic divergence does not occur in the perturbation calculation. The divergence we must renormalize is only logarithmic one, and there is no fine-tuning problem.
(b) According to the lattice model, which strictly preserves local gauge invariance at each stage of argument, the vacuum expectation value (VEV) of the gauge-dependent quantity vanishes, if it is calculated without gauge fixing. Hence, if $h(x)$ follows $h(x) \rightarrow$ $h(x) \exp (i \theta(x))$ under $A_{\mu}(x) \rightarrow A_{\mu}(x)-i e^{-1} \partial_{\mu} \theta(x),\langle h(x)\rangle=0$ is unavoidable. (Elitzur-De Angelis-De Falco-Guerra theorem) [24][25]. This is because the local character of gauge symmetry effectively breaks the connection in the degrees of freedom defined at different space-time points. If the Higgs particle is an elementary particle, the gauge-fixing dependence for the finite $\langle h(x)\rangle$ does not match its fundamental nature. Instead of $v_{h}=\langle h(x)\rangle$, the present physical vacuum is characterized by $\langle\overline{0}| \int\left[\varphi^{\dagger}(0) \varphi(0)\right]^{2} d^{4} Y|\overline{0}\rangle$ in Eq.(24). Because this condensate is gauge invariant, there is no need to worry about the vanishing of its VEV.
(c) The kinematical breaking does not end with the massless fermion and antifermion in the physical vacuum. Due to $\bar{\varphi}\left(i \partial_{\mu}+e B_{\mu}\right) \gamma^{\mu} \varphi$, the massless fermion-antifermion pair annihilate to a gauge boson, and this gauge boson annihilates to other massless fermion-antifermion pair in $|\overline{0}\rangle$. Such a process between massless objects possesses no threshold energy, and therefore it ends with an equilibrium state. At each point in space, the $U(1)$ gauge field $B_{\mu}$ condenses in the form of $F^{\mu \nu}(x) F_{\mu \nu}(x)$. The free vacuum $|0\rangle$ in the right-hand side of Eq.(7) should be replaced by a condensed vacuum $\left|0_{r}\right\rangle$ satisfying $\left\langle 0_{r}\right| F^{\mu \nu}(x) F_{\mu \nu}(x)\left|0_{r}\right\rangle \equiv\langle\vec{t}\rangle \neq 0$. This $\langle\vec{t}\rangle$ is a material constant of vacuum, and we should redefine $|0\rangle$ by $\left|0_{r}\right\rangle$ in the right-hand side of Eq.(7). (The explicit form of $\left|0_{r}\right\rangle$ is to be studied in the future.)
(d) The vacuum is often probed using the operator-product expansion in the deep inelastic scattering of pair annihilation of electron and positron to hadrons. For the cross section of

this experiment, following vacuum condensates are assumed

$$
\sigma\left(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow \text {hadrons }\right)=\frac{4 \pi \alpha^{2}}{s}\left[\operatorname{Im} c^{1}\left(q^{2}\right)+\operatorname{Im} c^{\bar{\varphi} \varphi}\langle 0| m \bar{\varphi} \varphi|0\rangle+\operatorname{Im} c^{F^{2}}\left(q^{2}\right)\left\langle 0\left(F_{\alpha \beta}^{a}\right)^{2} \mid 0\right\rangle+\cdots\right]
$$

Such $\langle 0| m \bar{\varphi} \varphi|0\rangle$ and $\left\langle 0\left(F_{\alpha \beta}^{a}\right)^{2} \mid 0\right\rangle$ may play some role in symmetry breaking as well. The interpretation of this paper may have some implication for this guess.
(e) In the Higgs potential, $\lambda\left|v_{h}+h_{1}+i h_{2}\right|^{4}$ predicts the triple and quartic self-couplings of the Higgs particle $h_{1}$. More complex many-body effects than that in Figure 4 may correspond to such self couplings. So far, the agreement of the GWS model to experiments of electroweak interaction is satisfactory. When more precise measurements are performed, however, there is a possibility of deviation, especially for light quarks and leptons of the first and second generations. The above $\widetilde{L}(x)$ predicts some different results from those by the BEH model. The next subject is to extend it to the electroweak interaction.

Appendix A: The physical vacuum $|\widetilde{0}\rangle$ satisfying $\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$
The vacuum satisfying $\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$ is as follows. In the expansion

$$
e^{-i K} F e^{i K}=F+[-i K, F]+\frac{1}{2!}[-i K,[-i K, F]]+\cdots
$$

we regard an operator $a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})$ or $b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})$ as $F$, and a following operator as $K$,

$$
i \sum_{p, s} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}\left[b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})-a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})\right]
$$

Hence, we can rewrite Eqs.(5) and (6) in a compact form

$$
\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})=e^{-i K} a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) e^{i K}, \quad \widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})=e^{-i K} b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p}) e^{i K}
$$

The vacuum satisfying $\widetilde{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=\widetilde{b}^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})|\widetilde{0}\rangle=0$ is simply expressed as $|\widetilde{0}\rangle=e^{-i K}|0\rangle$. Hence, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\widetilde{0}\rangle & =\exp \left(\sum_{p, s} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}\left[b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})-a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})\right]\right)|0\rangle \\
& =\prod_{p, s}\left[\sum_{n} \frac{1}{n!} \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}^{n}\left[b^{s \dagger}(-\boldsymbol{p}) a^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p})-a^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) b^{s}(-\boldsymbol{p})\right]^{n}\right]|0\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

The massless fermions and antifermions in the many-body state obey Fermi statistics, and therefore only a single particle can occupy each state. The sum over $n$ in Eq.(A4) is written for each $\boldsymbol{p}$ as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{n} \frac{\theta^{n}}{n!}\left(b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger}-a b\right)^{n}|0\rangle & =|0\rangle+\theta b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger}|0\rangle-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2!} a b b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger}|0\rangle-\frac{\theta^{3}}{3!} b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger} a b b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger}|0\rangle \\
& +\frac{\theta^{4}}{4!} a b b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger} a b b^{\dagger} a^{\dagger}|0\rangle+\cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

In this expansion, $\cos \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}$ appears in the sum of even-order terms of $\theta$, and $\sin \theta_{\boldsymbol{p}}$ appears in the sum of odd-order terms, and then Eq.(7) is yielded.

# Appendix B: Statistical gap 

(1) Consider a Bose field $f(x)$ with the following kinetic energy

$$
H_{e f}=-\int d^{3} x f^{\dagger}(x) \Delta f(x)
$$

Using differential geometry, one can systematically deals with the Laplacian operator in the shrinkable space.

The square of the infinitesimal line-element in the shrinkable space is a quadratic function of $d x$ as $d l^{2}=g_{\mu \nu}(x) d x^{\mu} d x^{\nu}$, where $g_{\mu \nu}(x)$ is a metric tensor characterizing the shrinkable space $(\mu, \nu=x, y, z)$, In this space, the inner product of the field $f(x)$ is defined as

$$
\langle f(x) \mid f(x)\rangle=\int \sqrt{g(x)} d^{3} x f^{\dagger}(x) f(x)
$$

where $g(x)$ is a determinant of $g_{\mu \nu}(x)$. Consider a gradient of $f$ like $A^{\mu}=g_{\mu \nu} \partial f / \partial x^{\nu}$. Since the metric depends on the position, a derivative of a given vector $A^{\mu}$ with respect to $x^{\mu}$ is replaced by the covariant derivative as follows

$$
\frac{D A^{\mu}}{d x^{\mu}}=\frac{d A^{\mu}}{d x^{\mu}}+\Gamma_{\nu \mu}^{\mu} A^{\nu}
$$

where $\Gamma_{\nu \mu}^{\mu}$ is a connection coefficient. This connection coefficient is expressed by the determinant of the metric tensor $g(x)=\left|g_{\mu \nu}(x)\right|$ as follows

$$
\Gamma_{\nu \mu}^{\mu}=\frac{1}{2 g} \frac{\partial g}{\partial x^{\nu}}
$$

With this expression, the covariant derivative of $A^{\mu}$ is given by

$$
\frac{D A^{\mu}}{d x^{\mu}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \frac{\partial\left(\sqrt{g} A^{\mu}\right)}{\partial x^{\mu}}
$$

(2) One can use Eq.(B5) to study the Laplacian $D \partial f / \partial^{2} x$. The matrix element of the Laplacian operator is obtained by inserting $D \partial / \partial^{2} x$ between $f^{\dagger}(x)$ and $f(x)$ in Eq.(B2), and using Eq.(B5) with $A^{\mu}=g_{\mu \nu} \partial f / \partial x^{\nu}$ for $D \partial f / \partial^{2} x$. After integration by parts, we get

$$
\langle f(x) \mid \Delta \mid f(x)\rangle=\int \sqrt{g} d^{3} x f^{\dagger} \frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\mu}}\left(\sqrt{g} g_{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right)=\int \sqrt{g(x)} g_{\mu \nu} d^{3} x \frac{\partial f^{\dagger}}{\partial x^{\mu}} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^{\nu}}
$$

Our interest is how the effect of permutation symmetry looks in the flat space, because we observe it as an effect of Bose statistics in experiments. We introduce a new field $\widehat{f}(x)=g(x)^{1 / 4} f(x)$ to rewrite Eq.(B6) in the flat space as follows

$$
\int \sqrt{g(x)} d^{3} x f^{\dagger}(x) f(x)=\int d^{3} x \widehat{f}^{\dagger}(x) \widehat{f}(x)
$$

The gradient in the shrinkable space is rewritten using $\widehat{f}(x)$ as if it is in the real space

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=g^{-1 / 4}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}-\frac{1}{4} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x}\right) \widehat{f}(x)
$$

Hence, the matrix element of Laplacian in Eq.(B6)

$$
\langle f(x) \mid \Delta \mid f(x)\rangle=\int d^{3} x g_{\mu \nu}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\mu}}-\frac{1}{4} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\mu}}\right) \widehat{f}^{\dagger}(x)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\nu}}-\frac{1}{4} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right) \widehat{f}(x)
$$

is rewritten using the integration by parts as follows

$$
\langle f(x) \mid \Delta \mid f(x)\rangle=\int d^{3} x g_{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial \widehat{f}^{\dagger}}{\partial x^{\mu}} \frac{\partial \widehat{f}}{\partial x^{\nu}}+\int W(x) \widehat{f}^{\dagger}(x) \widehat{f}(x) d^{3} x
$$

where

$$
W(x)=\frac{1}{4} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\mu}}\left(g_{\mu \nu} \frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right)+\frac{1}{16} g_{\mu \nu}\left(\frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\mu}}\right)\left(\frac{\partial \ln g}{\partial x^{\nu}}\right)
$$

This $W(x)$ is the square of the finite energy gap in the excitation spectrum of $\widehat{f}(x)$ [21].

$$
i \psi(x)=\int \frac{d^{3} p}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \sum_{s} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 E_{p}}}\left[\widehat{u}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}) \widehat{u}^{s}(p) e^{-i p x}+\widehat{b}^{s \dagger}(\boldsymbol{p}) \widehat{v}^{s}(p) e^{i p x}\right]
$$

where $\widehat{u}^{s}(p)$ and $\widehat{v}^{s}(-p)$ are the massive spinor eigen functions, and $\widehat{a}(\boldsymbol{p}) \equiv(2 \pi)^{3 / 2} \widehat{a}(\boldsymbol{p}) / \sqrt{V}$ and $\widehat{b}(\boldsymbol{p}) \equiv(2 \pi)^{3 / 2} \widehat{b}(\boldsymbol{p}) / \sqrt{V}$ satisfy $\left\{\widehat{a}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}), \widehat{a}^{\dagger, s^{\prime}}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}\right)\right\}=\left\{\widehat{b}^{s}(\boldsymbol{p}), \widehat{b}^{\dagger, s^{\prime}}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}\right)\right\}=(2 \pi)^{3} \delta\left(\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{\prime}\right) \delta_{s, s^{\prime}}$.

abstract:
A new interpretation of the Brout-Englert-Higgs (BEH) mechanism is proposed.
The quantum vacuum before symmetry is broken is not a quiet state, but a
relativistic many-body state in which virtual massless fermion and antifermion,
taking both timelike and spacelike paths, rapidly appear and disappear. In
order to give a physical meaning to their many-body state, they should be
described so that they move along a common direction of time from the past to
the future, even if they are observed from any inertial fame. The state
satisfying this kinematical condition is examined, and as its
lowest-energy-state, the broken-symmetry vacuum is derived. Since it is a
kinematical breaking of symmetry, the interaction is freed from the role of
causing symmetry breaking. Whatever effective interaction is there, it induces
the motion of others, then turns out to be an inertial mass of the fermion or
antifermion. In this physical vacuum, virtual massless fermion and antifermion
always appear as pairs, and they behave as quasi bosons. Due to Bose
statistics, their transverse excitations are suppressed by an energy gap, which
explains the origin of the vacuum condensate in the BEH mechanism. The dynamic
part of the above effective interaction induces a Higgs-like excitation. This
interpretation sheds a new light on the BEH mechanism.
